description.en: AREMA Ontology for building materials, buildings, natural resources, professionals, and technical constructions.

definition.en: Materials used for construction purposes, including natural and manufactured substances.
Building materials characterized by their mass and solidity, such as concrete or rammed earth.
Modular building materials typically made of fired clay or similar substances, used in masonry construction.
Prefabricated flat building components, often used for walls, floors, and ceilings.
Loose construction materials used in large quantities, such as gravel or sand.
A mixture used in masonry to bond bricks, stones, or concrete blocks together.
Timber or lumber derived from trees, commonly used in building structures and finishes.
Physical structures intended for human use or occupancy, such as houses, offices, and public buildings.
Classification of buildings based on the type of intervention, such as new construction or renovation.
Buildings that are newly constructed and not previously used or occupied.
Buildings undergoing repair, improvement, or modernization.
Buildings containing multiple separate residential units.
Residential buildings designed for occupancy by a single family.
Buildings primarily used for commercial office purposes.
Buildings intended for use by the public, such as schools, libraries, or government offices.
Basic or minimal buildings or structures, typically with limited complexity or use.
Naturally occurring substances or materials that can be used for construction, manufacturing, or energy production.
Soil or clay materials used in construction, often in traditional building techniques.
Natural stone materials used in construction for strength and durability.
Dried stalks of grain plants used as a natural building material, often in combination with earth.
Fibrous plant material used for insulation, blocks, and other eco-friendly construction purposes.
Timber or lumber derived from trees, commonly used in building structures and finishes.
Various plant-based or synthetic fibers used as components in construction materials.
Persons or organizations providing expertise or services within the construction or building sectors.
A professional responsible for designing buildings and overseeing their construction.
A professional specializing in the design, construction, and maintenance of infrastructure and buildings.
A skilled worker specializing in manual trades related to construction, such as carpentry or masonry.
A company or individual involved in the production and supply of construction materials.
A specialist focusing on the physical properties of buildings, including thermal, acoustic, and energy performance.
An organization representing the interests of professionals within the construction sector.
A company engaged in building construction projects and services.
Aspects of construction related to the physical realization of buildings, encompassing structural, thermal, acoustic, and service-related elements.
Measures and design elements intended to prevent, contain, and mitigate the effects of fire within a building.
Techniques and materials used to reduce the transfer of heat between the inside and outside of a building.
Strategies and components used to prevent moisture infiltration and control humidity in building structures.
Methods and materials designed to reduce the transmission of sound between and within building spaces.
The system of structural elements that support and transfer the weight and forces of a building to the ground.
Construction techniques emphasizing minimal material usage and weight while maintaining structural integrity.
Technical systems installed in buildings, such as heating, ventilation, plumbing, and electrical infrastructure.
The physical separator between the interior and exterior of a building, including walls, roofs, and windows.
The process of manufacturing building components off-site for later assembly on-site.
The process of improving, modernizing, or restoring an existing building.
The systematic dismantling of a building with the goal of preserving materials for reuse or recycling.
Technical construction topics not covered by the predefined categories.
